Award.AwardTitle: Coastal SEES (Track 1): Understanding the links between local ecological knowledge, ecosystem services, and community resilience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human and natural systems are interlinked in complex ways. Understanding how these social-ecological systems are and can be resilient poses one of the most pressing problems of our world today. This is especially true for many coastal communities, which are vulnerable to changes. The local ecological knowledge systems developed over millennia have historically allowed residents of coastal communities to be resilient to the weather extremes that can characterize coastal communities. However, the complex patterns and processes involved in these systems, and their potential to enhance resilience to climate change today are poorly understood. This research is grounded in a conceptual framework that integrates social-ecological resilience theory and methods, ethnobiology and ecosystem service modeling. It draws on a combination of long-term existing social and ecological datasets, new experiments, and state-of the art climate and ecosystem service modeling in multiple sites to ask: (1) What are the relationships between local ecological knowledge systems and social-ecological resilience to change? and (2) How will different land and ocean uses affect social-ecological resilience and ecosystem services in linked ridge-reef settings, under different scenarios? This research involves an interdisciplinary, international research team that crosses the natural and social sciences and bridges the marine and terrestrial fields.

This research is expected to have direct benefits to society by enhancing local capacity in decision making to manage coastal areas for sustainability, and contributing to policy development in resilience and adaptation to climate change. It is integrated with interdisciplinary and international educational and training activities for undergraduate and graduate students, especially members of groups underrepresented in the sciences. It will strengthen and extend an interdisciplinary cross-national network of researchers and resource managers. The models produced will provide predictive value for the management of Pacific Island coastal systems by identifying how ecosystem services and social-ecological resilience can be maximized.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human and natural systems are interlinked in complex ways. Understanding how these social-ecological systems are and can be resilient to climate change poses one of the most pressing problems of our world today. This is especially true for coastal communities in the Pacific Islands, which are highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. This project brought together an interdisciplinary team of researchers and students who worked collaboratively with resource managers and local communities to better understand the nature of social-ecological linkages in coastal communities in Hawaii and Fiji, and how these can be important for fostering both biodiversity conservation and community resilience ro climate change.

We developed a new quantitative approach to identify linkages among indicators of biodiversity conservation and community resilience and showed how these are intimately connected in ways not previously understood.  We also developed spatially explicit ecosystem service models to help identify land-uses and ocean uses that can best maximize both ecosystem services and community resilience in the context of climate change. We applied them across a range of systems and contexts in coastal communities in Hawaii and Fiji to help inform decision-making related to land-use, coral reef conservation, forest restoration, and the food-energy-water nexus. This work involved the development of a set of new methodologies that were needed to address these questions in island contexts.  These included a novel integrated land-sea model to identify linkages between land management practices and coral reef health and resilience, a framework for identifying indigenous cultural values in ecosystem service assessments, new methodologies to quantify water yield and fire risk in tropical island ecosystems, and a reef fish vulnerability index for Hawaii. These modeling approaches are now being used elsewhere to help inform decision-making for sustainability. Our research showed how incorporating cultural values and land-sea linkages into the decision-making process can change the outcomes, highlighting the importance of understanding these factors.

Our research was deeply integrated with interdisciplinary educational and training activities. This included an international field course and exchange (between University of Hawaii and University of the South Pacific -Fiji students), modeling workshops, graduate seminars on interdisciplinary research, and individual mentoring. We trained a group of eight graduate students and two postdoctoral students who now have the experience and capacity to effectively carry out sustainability science research in interdisciplinary and international teams, and to communicate the results to multiple stakeholders. Of these students, seven are women, and three are underrepresented minorities in science (Hawaiians/Pacific Islanders). We have also provided research assistantship opportunities in Hawaii and Fiji for 10 undergraduates, 9 of whom were Hawaiian or Pacific Islanders. And additional 13 students from Hawaii and other parts of the Pacific Islands participated in at least one of our workshops or courses.  Through our work we also strengthened and extended an interdisciplinary Pacific Island network of academic researchers, resource managers and cultural practitioners who have since developed new projects together.

To date, our research has been communicated in 11 peer-reviewed publications, with multiple other manuscripts in review or revision. It has also been shared with the broader public through meetings with government and intergovernmental agencies, non-profits, large private land-owners, local communities and local schools. Our research results have led directly to the funding of new, on-the-ground activities to enhance sustainability in coastal communities in Hawaii and Fiji by two of our partner organizations. Overall, our research has had direct benefits to society by enhancing local capacity in decision making to manage coastal areas for sustainability.
